text: <@U0542GLTE>: THREAD_POOL_EXECUTOR is a static in Async task, would be shared across all async task instance, what wrong did i say?
please explain if u very smart <@U04U5KS3Z>
dont even wanna try? <@U04U5KS3Z>
async tasks are pretty delicate and prone to issues like memory leaks
who said?
if u dont use it properly it can cause memory leaks
if u pass callback reference to task & don’t nullify it when ur UI component is being killed, then definitly there will be leak
same happens with Rx, thats y u need to call subscriptionObject.unsubscribe, this is general threading concept, u can’t blame async task for this
:open_mouth: why don’t we calm down a little here and agree to disagree
AsyncTask promotes bad implementations a lot more than other apporaches, but if it works for you, then yay.

I m just saying there are no side effects of using it, just introduces lots boilerplate code otherwise it works fine.
I agree there are better approaches for doing the same thing more declaratively with less code.

<@U1KBFNA4R|ma> has joined the channel
its kinda stupid question, but how to convert this `2016-06-22T08:50:36.733` time format to for.ex. `June 22 2016` ?
what date time library are you using?
We use joda
but its should be pretty simple with native JAVA API
I can convert to `Wed Jun 22 08:50:36 EDT 2016`, but then I don’t want to have a deal with substring and stuff
yeah, the first format is just the ISO standard format, so once you have it in a DateTime object, you can call `toString` with a `DateTimeFormatter`
i believe the format you are looking for is called long date
I have a date string from the server
`DateTime.parse`
it takes a string
yeah
so do `DateTime.parse(str).toString(DateTimeFormat.longDate())`
why are you using simpledateformat?
why not
because it means you are dealing with java `Date` objects, which is bad
if you have joda, use it. never use a java Date if you can avoid it
there are serious bugs in the java Date stuff. that's why they replaced it with calendar, and replaced that with JSR 310
<@U1KBFNA4R>: that's not very localizable
<@U0JBR7LUV>: seriously, if you are already using joda, just use it everywhere. you can also use jake wharton's android 310 backport
yeah you’re right, not the best solution but something quick to show SimpleDateFormat
joda just works perfect, thanks
np
I used SimpleDateFormat because I was needed to find the difference between today and date from the server
joda does that better
in which way please
i assume you want the number of days/hours between today and the date some server output?
yeah, I think hours the best
date from server is like this `2016-06-22T08:50:36.733`
`new Duration(date1, date2).toStandardHours()`
full thing would be something like `new Duration(DateTime.now(), DateTime.parse(dateStr)).toStandardHours()`
cool, thank you very much!!!
my pleasure
<@U1HL9UB7B>: what does `PT` mean, like Pacific Time or something ?
can i see the whole string?
in a sec
ok, you mean in the duration?
sorry, gradle :disappointed:
yes
it's the ISO spec for durations
I should add that, if you *don't* have Joda, don't add it just to use it. Treat yourself to the beauty of the Java 8 time API <https://github.com/JakeWharton/ThreeTenABP>

attachments.title: JakeWharton/ThreeTenABP
attachments.text: ThreeTenABP - An adaptation of the JSR-310 backport for Android.

text: btw, shorter version of what i gave your earlier: `Hours.hoursBetween(date1, date2)`
Ah yeah, I see now that you said that, toadzky
<@U1HL4NZK7>: i did mention that to him, but he said they already have joda
Link for the lazy, still, I suppose :slightly_smiling_face:
:slightly_smiling_face:
<@U0JBR7LUV>: the `PT` stuff is what you will get if you use the `toString` method. if you just want the count as an int, call `getHours`
so something like `int difference = Hours.hoursBetween(DateTime.now(), DateTime.parse(dateStr)).getHours()`
have done this :slightly_smiling_face:
thanks <@U1HL9UB7B> and <@U1HL4NZK7>

and if its a pre L samsung.. throw it away its not worth your sanity
android has such a terrible history with Bluetooth in general, it’s a shame
well bluetooth has a history of generally being terrible so its not really all google’s fault
it’s not perfect, but it’s definitely worse on android
I dont know about that
try OSX bluetooth issues and tell me you really think apple did better
ios also has tons of problems, bluetooth is just bad
my iOS experience with BLE is none, but with Bluetooth in general I’ve not had many issues
sounds lovely

text: that’s someone’s opinion on the matter
all I’m saying is you can’t say it works well on iphone and ignore that in the rest of the ecosystem it doesn’t work
android may have the worst implementation but even the best isn’t great
its not like wifi is what I am getting at which basically always works
oh sure
no, the spec has its issues, without a doubt
but I’ve seen multiple cases where a client has an iOS implementation of an app that relies on BLE or Bluetooth in general and the Android implementation suffers because the Bluetooth stack is shit
that article is practically ancient now, hopefully things have improved since then
is it possible that the cache directory deletes files during runtime without a warning?
I’m feeling like the worst engineer because I can’t figure out why in an incremental branch all of the sudden files that I put on the cache went “poof” mid execution
without any input from my side
they live, they hit UniversalImageLoader cache (don’t ask), then when I try to re-fetch them later they’re vanished!
but it’s been working on branch Monday
and it stopped on branch Wednesday
it seems to have fixed itself by changing the storage dir from Cache to Files but still
fuck me
of course a cache can delete files at runtime. that's what a cache directory is
it's temporary storage where things get expired from the cache and cleaned up when the space is needed
but why in one branch and not on another
I didn’t add anything extra on the cache
not enough information for me to diagnose that
cache files are typically cleaned up when the device needs more storage space
don’t worry, I’m just annoyed
yeah, but why would that happen on the space of 1 second
TTL on the cache entry maybe?
add image, see it on screen, hit save to remote endpoint
again, without looking at the code, the cache config, etc. i can't tell you that
yep

text: <@U1HL9UB7B>: i have another question, so I’m trying to implement a listener for a switch, but i’m looking at the docs and it says something about onSharedPreferenceChangeListener
i’m just confused on how to implement it, because i’m confused as to what SharedPreferences is and what it refers to, and how to get it to refer specifically to my specific switch change

<@U1HLGB8AE>: you should read through the android developer docs. short version is that the UI is auto generated from the preferences file and automatically changes the settings so the listener to implement is the one that fires when a setting is changed. but definitely start reading the developer docs, because if you don't know what sharedpreferences are, you need to learn about the platform sdk and apis before you go any further
